information:
The 2025 Derbyshire County Council election is scheduled for May 1, 2025. This election will use new divisional boundaries, increasing the total number of seats from 61 to 64. Elections for the council operate under a First-Past-The-Post system. According to an assessment, the Conservative Party holds 57 of the 64 seats under the new boundaries. Reform UK currently holds zero seats on the council.

As a newer political party, Reform UK does not have the established local infrastructure and grassroots organization of the main parties active in Derbyshire. The party has encountered issues with candidate vetting, including a controversy involving their candidate for Bakewell, Max Bethell, who reportedly made racial slurs on social media. Historically, predecessor parties like UKIP and the Brexit Party did not succeed in translating national support into control of county councils.

National polling data shows support for Reform UK at approximately 23-25%. A March MRP poll by The Telegraph provided data for the region. The party has confirmed it is running a full slate of candidates across Derbyshire. Political scientist Professor John Curtice has noted that Reform UK's voter support may be more geographically concentrated than widely distributed.

forecast.status_quo_outcome: The Conservative Party maintains control with overwhelming majority, currently holding 57 of 64 seats under new boundaries. Reform UK holds zero seats.
forecast.no_outcome_scenario: Reform UK makes some gains but fails to overcome the massive Conservative advantage. The established parties maintain dominance through superior local infrastructure, name recognition, and proven track record. Reform UK's lack of grassroots organization and candidate controversies limit their appeal to voters, and their support doesn't translate efficiently to seat wins under First-Past-The-Post.
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: Reform UK achieves an unprecedented electoral surge in the final 10 days, converting their national polling numbers (23-25%) into highly efficient local seat wins. Their geographically concentrated support aligns perfectly with electoral divisions, and a massive anti-establishment wave combined with Conservative collapse allows them to win 33+ seats from a standing start of zero.
forecast.rationale:
This forecast requires assessing the likelihood of one of the most dramatic swings in British local government history. The status quo is overwhelming: Conservatives hold 57 of 64 seats, while Reform UK holds zero. To win the most seats, Reform UK would need to capture at least 33 seats in just 10 days - an unprecedented achievement for a party with no current council representation.

Several factors make this extremely unlikely: (1) Reform UK lacks the local infrastructure and grassroots organization essential for local election success; (2) First-Past-The-Post electoral systems historically disadvantage insurgent parties, making it difficult to convert vote share into seats; (3) Candidate vetting issues, including the Bakewell controversy, undermine their credibility; (4) Historical precedent shows predecessor parties like UKIP and Brexit Party failed to control county councils despite national support; (5) There are only 10 days remaining, insufficient time for the dramatic shift required.

While Reform UK's 23-25% national polling and full slate of candidates suggest some level of competitiveness, national polling doesn't directly translate to local council seats, especially in conservative-leaning counties. The geographic concentration of support mentioned by Prof. Curtice could help in specific divisions but is unlikely to be sufficient for overall control.

My forecast is not higher because there is no evidence of Reform UK being competitive for majority control in Derbyshire specifically, and the structural barriers are immense. It's not lower (i.e., not 0%) because electoral politics can occasionally produce shocking results, and with 10 days remaining there is technically still time for dramatic developments, however improbable. To update upward, I would need to see: credible local polling showing Reform UK leading in 30+ divisions, major defections to Reform UK, or evidence of catastrophic Conservative collapse. To update downward, evidence that Reform UK is struggling even in their target divisions would push this closer to zero.
